0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono:
• Acquired factor VIII deficiency disease - Bleeding: Mild and moderate hemorrhage: Initial, 200 units per kg IV (rate, 1 to 2 mL/min) every 4 to 12 hours; base subsequent dosage on factor VIII trough levels and clinical response; required factor VIII level, 50 to 100 units/dL or 50% to 100% of normal; do not exceed factor VIII plasma levels 200% of normal or 200 units per dL
  • Acquired factor VIII deficiency disease - Bleeding: Major hemorrhage: Initial, 200 units per kg IV (rate, 1 to 2 mL/min) every 4 to 12 hours; base subsequent dosage on factor VIII trough levels and clinical response; required factor VIII level, 100 to 200 units/dL or 100% to 200% of normal to treat acute bleed, followed by 50 to 100 units/dL or 50% to 100% of normal once acute bleed is controlled and if required; do not exceed factor VIII plasma levels 200% of normal or 200 units per dL

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono: Safety and efficacy not established in pediatric patients

3.title: Indications
3.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
Acquired factor VIII deficiency disease - Bleeding

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: history of life-threatening hypersensitivity reactions to antihemophilic factor (recombinant) porcine sequence or its components, including hamster protein

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Immunologic:
  • -- hypersensitivity reactions may occur, possibly progressing to anaphylaxis; discontinue immediately if allergic or anaphylactic-type reactions occur
  • -- development of inhibitory antibodies to antihemophilic factor have been reported; monitoring recommended

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Antihemophilic factor (recombinant) porcine sequence provides temporary replacement of inhibited endogenous factor VIII in patients with acquired hemophilia A.

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Intravenous
  • Recombinant porcine factor VIII potency in units is stated on each vial
  • Vials must be reconstituted prior to use; bring vial and prefilled diluent syringe to room temperature prior to reconstitution
  • Peel back cover of vial adapter package but leave adapter in plastic package
  • Remove plastic package from vial adapter to expose the filter spike
  • Firmly push filter spike through center of rubber circle on vial until clear plastic cap connects to vial
  • Push plunger down gently to inject all of diluent from syringe into vial
  • Swirl vial gently to mix, leaving syringe in place
  • Use reconstituted product within 3 hours when stored at room temperature
  • If more than one vial is required, reconstitute each using instructions above
  • Do not administer with other infusion medications using same tubing or container
  • Connect large syringe to Luer lock of vial adapter; turn clockwise until syringe is secure
  • Withdraw reconstituted antihemophilic factor (recombinant) porcine sequence into syringe
  • Repeat above process with all prepared vials to reach volume needed for administration
  • Administer IV at rate of 1 to 2 mL per minute

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• control or reduction in bleeding indicates efficacy
  • 1-stage clotting assay to confirm adequate plasma VIII levels, 30 minutes and 3 hours after initial dose, then 30 minutes after subsequent doses.
  • plasma factor VIII levels for adequate response, especially with life-threatening bleeding or major surgery
  • plasma factor VIII inhibitor (neutralizing antibodies) levels; if inadequate response to appropriate doses
  • aPTT normalization should not be used as an efficacy measurement
  • clinical signs of factor VIII inhibitor formation

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono: Advise patient to report a hypersensitivity reaction.
